newsitem.title: AUSTRIA: Austria Tabak swings into black ahead of float.
newsitem.headline: Austria Tabak swings into black ahead of float.

text.p: Tobacco monopoly Austria Tabak on Thursday posted record 1996 earnings and a massive swing into the black and said the result proved it was fit for privatisation and flotation.
The company turned in a group net profit of 1.3 billion schillings ($106.9 million) after a loss of 1.1 billion in 1995 and painted an upbeat picture for the year ahead.

"A conservative forecast for 1997 is that we will certainly match last year's excellent result and bring growing shareholder value," chairman Heinz Schiendl said during a news conference on the results.
Pretax profit jumped 27 percent to 1.8 billion and earnings before interest and tax (EBIT) gained 17 percent to 1.6 billion.
The government placed Austria Tabak in the hands of state holding company OeIAG last August to prepare it for privatisation.
OeIAG chief Karl Hollweger said Austria Tabak could be privatised and floated on the Vienna stock exchange in November at the earliest.
"Austria Tabak is a very attractive flotation candidate and I'm confident we can take the first step this year," he told reporters at the news conference.
OeIAG's envisages selling off 75 percent of Austria Tabak in two tranches by the end of 1999, with OeIAG holding the remaining 25 percent.
The first tranche would likely be 25 percent, "but if market conditions are favourable, we could float the bigger tranche first," Hollweger said.
"I can't say what the proceeds will be from the flotation, but judging from Austria Tabak's earnings performance last year it will surely be a respectable sum."
Austria Tabak said its recovery was helped by the sale of lossmaking sports equipment maker Head-Tyrolia-Mares (HTM) in September, 1995.
Group sales rose three percent to 58.3 billion schillings, with sales in Austria receding but increasing abroad.
"We've got to be realistic and see that sales will continue to fall on the Austrian market, but we expect to increase sales in international markets," said Austria Tabak's Schiendl.
It will focus on developing new markets, with particular emphasis on Asia.
Austria tabak is already the largest wholesaler of cigarettes in Germany through its subsidiary Tobaccoland Deutschland.

At home, the company enjoys a commanding presence, with its own brands accounting for 60 percent of the market, while brands produced by Austria Tabak under license hold a further 35 percent. ($ = 12.16 Austrian Schillings)
